snippet: The decision to end the case appeared to represent both a triumph for President Uhuru Kenyatta and a display of the difficulties involved in prosecuting leaders.
abstract: Fatou Bensouda, chief prosecutor of International Criminal Court, withdraws charges against Kenya's Pres Uhuru Kenyatta of crimes against humanity; Kenyatta, first sitting president to appear before court, was accused of helping to orchestrate and finance a wave of ethnic violence after disputed elections in 2007, charges he has always denied.

byline.original: By MARLISE SIMONS and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
byline.contributor: Marlise Simons reported from Paris, and Jeffrey Gettleman from Freetown, Sierra Leone. Alan Cowell contributed reporting from London, and Reuben Kyama from Nairobi, Kenya.

lead_paragraph: The decision to end the case appeared to represent both a triumph for President Uhuru Kenyatta and a display of the difficulties involved in prosecuting leaders.

headline.seo: Uhuru Kenyatta Faced Allegations of Crimes Against Humanity
headline.main: International Court Ends Case Against Kenyan President in Election Unrest
headline.print_headline: International Court Ends Case Against Kenyan President in Election Unrest

keywords.value: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
